1. What is the Premiere Pro C++ SDK and where to download it?
2. What types of plugins can be built (importers, exporters, effects, transitions, etc.)?
3. Is there a plugin type that can manipulate the timeline/sequence directly (cut, razor, split clips)?

5. How does the C++ SDK bridge/communicate with UXP JavaScript plugins?
6. What is the project structure for a C++ SDK plugin?
7. What build tools are required (Visual Studio, Xcode, CMake)?
8. Are there sample projects that demonstrate timeline manipulation?

This is research only - provide detailed findings on the C++ SDK architecture and capabilities for timeline editing operations. Do not write code.

Here's what I found about the Adobe Premiere Pro C++ SDK download and official documentation:

## Official Download Location

The latest release of the SDK is available at: https://www.adobe.io/apis/creativecloud/premierepro.html(no content)The SDK enables you to build powerful, low-level integrations using C++. The documentation is packaged with the SDK.

## Adobe Developer Portal

The primary official source is the **Adobe Developer Portal** at [developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/).

If you get "Restricted Access" when trying to download the C++ SDK and documentation, try logging in with a Personal account.

## Documentation Resources

- **Premiere Pro C++ SDK Guide**: Available at [ppro-plugins.docsforadobe.dev](https://ppro-plugins.docsforadobe.dev/) - This is a living document, and is constantly being updated and edited.

- If you have questions about the APIs described in the documentation, or about integration with Premiere Pro, your question may already be answered on the Premiere Pro SDK forum at the Adobe Community.

## SDK Capabilities

The Premiere Pro Software Development Kit enables developers to create plugins for Premiere Pro, After Effects, Audition, Media Encoder, Character Animator, and Premiere Elements.

The SDK supports developing:
Panel Plugins (UXP/CEP Extensions) – Custom UI panels for automation. Video Effects Plugins – Custom filters, LUTs, and overlays. Transition Plugins – Custom wipe, dissolve, and animation transitions. Audio Effects Plugins – EQ, noise reduction, and AI-powered enhancements. File Import & Export Automation – Batch processing for video files.

## Important Note

Many Premiere Pro plugins use the After Effects SDK — They may need the Premiere Pro headers. According to Adobe support, "The C++ SDK is complete, and used without issue by our C++ plugin developers."

Based on my search results, here's what I found about the Premiere Pro SDK for timeline and sequence manipulation in C++:

## Premiere Pro C++ SDK - Timeline and Sequence Manipulation

The Adobe Premiere Pro Software Development Kit is a living document that is constantly being updated and edited. The latest release of the SDK is available at https://www.adobe.io/apis/creativecloud/premierepro.html.

### Key APIs for Timeline/Sequence Work

**Video Segment Suite**
This suite provides calls to parse a sequence and get details on video segments. All the queryable node properties are in PrSDKVideoSegmentProperties.h. These properties will be returned as PrSDKStrings, and should be managed using the String Suite.(no content)The segments provide a hash value that the caller can use to quickly determine whether or not a segment has changed. This hash value can be maintained even if a segment is shifted in time. In version 4, new in CS5.5, the new call AcquireNodeForTime() passes back a segment node for a requested time.(no content)To get a good idea of the segment structure, try the SDK player, create a sequence using the SDK Editing Mode, and watch the text overlay in the Sequence Monitor as you perform edits. See PrSDKVideoSegmentSuite.h and PrSDKVideoSegmentProperties.h.

**Legacy Callback Suites**
The piSuites structure includes PlugTimelineFuncsPtr timelineFuncs for timeline operations, along with memory, window, ppix, and utility functions.

**Time Handling**
Most newer areas of the API use a tick-based time value that is stored in a signed 64-bit integer. Variables that use this new format are of type PrTime. When a frame rate is represented as a PrTime, the frame rate is the number of ticks in a frame duration. The current number of ticks per second must be retrieved using the callback in the Time Suite.

**Sequence Info Suite**
The Sequence Info Suite now provides a call to get the sequence frame rate, which may be useful for effects.(no content)The Sequence Info Suite can retrieve the field type, zero point, and whether or not the timecode is drop-frame.

### Working with Timeline Data

Starting in Premiere Pro 1.5, the importer can get a frame from the timeline beneath the current clip or timeline location. This is useful for titler plugins. Use the getPreviewFrameEx callback with the time given by TDB_TimeRecord tdbTimelocation in imGetPrefsRec.

### Community Resources

The premiere-plugin-guide GitHub repo hosts the Premiere C++ Plugin SDK Guide community docs. This endeavour is primarily community-supported and run; contributors are welcome and encouraged to suggest fixes, adjustments, notes/warnings, and anything else that may help the project.(no content)If you have questions about the APIs described in this document, or about integration with Premiere Pro, your question may already be answered on the Premiere Pro SDK forum at: https://community.adobe.com/t5/forums/filteredbylabelpage/board-id/premiere-pro/label-name/sdk.

Based on my search, here's information about Premiere Pro SDK plugin types including importers, exporters, effects, and transitions:

## Premiere Pro SDK Plugin Types

### Overview

With the Adobe Premiere Pro SDK, developers can build custom plugins that extend Premiere Pro's capabilities, from video effects and transitions to automated editing tools.

### Two Main Plugin Categories

There are two main plugin types in Premiere Pro: CEP Extensions (Common Extensibility Platform) – built using HTML, JavaScript, and CSS for UI-based plugins, and Native Plugins (C++ SDK) – built using C++ for deeper integration with video processing.

### Plugin File Formats

On Windows, Premiere Pro plugins must have the file extension ".prm". On macOS, they have the file extension ".bundle". Other supported plugin standards use their conventional file extensions: ".aex" for After Effects plugins, ".dll" for VST plugins.

### Importers

Importers provide video, audio and/or closed captioning from the media source. This source can be a single file, a set of files, a communication link between another application, etc. Standard importers appear as choices in the File > Import dialog, in the Files of type drop-down menu.(no content)Synthetic importers synthesize source material, rather than reading from disk. They appear in the File > New menu. Custom importers are a special type of synthetic importer, implemented to better support titlers. Custom importers can create files on disk; synthetic importers don't.

### Transitions

A transition plugin is a type of video effect that creates smooth movement between two video clips. Common transitions include: Fade In/Out – Gradual increase or decrease in opacity.(no content)Adobe has extended the After Effects API to support native transitions in Premiere Pro.

### Effects and GPU Support

GPU Extensions to existing APIs allow effects and transitions to access video frames in GPU memory, when using the Mercury Playback Engine in a GPU-accelerated mode.(no content)Premiere Pro supports third-party audio effects that use VST, VST3, and Audio Units (Audio Units is supported on macOS only). Premiere Pro supports these SDKs, and any effect written in those formats should work in Premiere Pro.

### Exporters

The importer and exporter APIs have been extended to support closed captioning embedded in media.(no content)Exporters can now get the list of source pixel formats used by the clips in a sequence that is being smart rendered.

### Plugin Architecture Details

Premiere plugins contain a single entry point of a type specific to each API. Plugins are DLLs on Windows, and Carbon or Cocoa Bundles on macOS.(no content)Only one plugin per file is parsed, unlike After Effects and Photoshop plugins, which can contain multiple entry points.

### Plugin Installation Location

Supported Premiere and After Effects plugins installed in the common plugins folder will be loaded by Premiere Pro, After Effects, Audition, and Media Encoder. Other plugin types, such as QuickTime and VfW codecs should be installed at the operating system level.

content.content:
# Premiere Pro Plugin Types (C++ SDK)

## Native Plugin Types

**1. Importers**
Purpose: "Import video and audio media into Premiere." Includes synthetic importers that generate media dynamically and custom importers that synthesize to disk.

**2. Export Controllers**
Purpose: "Can drive any exporter to generate a file in any format and perform custom post-processing operations." Designed for asset management system integration.

**3. Exporters**
Purpose: Enable users to save media to disk in various formats.

**4. Transmitters**
Purpose: "Sends video, audio, and closed captioning to any external device during playback and editing."

**5. Video Filters**
Purpose: "Process a series of video frames with parameters that can be animated over time." Adobe recommends using the After Effects SDK instead.

**6. GPU Effects & Transitions**
Purpose: "Process two video sources into a single destination over time," based on the After Effects API with transition-specific functions.

**7. Control Surfaces**
Purpose: "Interface with a hardware control surface to support audio mixing, basic transport controls, and the Lumetri Color panel" with bidirectional communication capabilities.

## Additional Supported Standards

The documentation also lists VST (audio effects), ASIO drivers, Core Audio (macOS), and After Effects API support as compatible plugin technologies.

content.content:
# SweetPea Suites APIs Overview

## Available Suites for Sequence/Timeline/Clip Manipulation

### Core Sequence & Clip Suites

**Video Segment Suite** - Parses sequence structure and retrieves details on video segments. It provides a tree-based hierarchy showing compositor nodes, clip nodes, media nodes, and operators (effects). The suite returns queryable properties as strings and includes hash values to detect segment changes.

**Video Segment Render Suite** - Enables built-in software rendering with subtree support, allowing plugins to request the host render specific portions while handling remaining compositing tasks.

**Sequence Info Suite** - Retrieves sequence metadata including "frame size and pixel aspect ratio" and frame rate information. Useful for importers, transitions, and filters needing sequence dimensions.

**Clip Render Suite** - Requests source frames directly from importers, with capabilities to discover supported frame sizes, pixel formats, and retrieve frames synchronously or asynchronously.

### Supporting Suites for Timeline Work

**Time Suite** - Converts between different time representations (ticks per second, video frames, audio samples) and defines frame rate enumerations.

**Marker Suite** - Reads markers of various types attached to sequences.

**Memory Manager Suite** - Manages memory allocation/deallocation and reserves space to prevent cache interference.

**PPix Suite & Related Creator Suites** - Handle pixel frame creation, copying, and buffer access for rendered content.

All suites are accessed through the Utilities Suite via `AcquireSuite()` and must be released when finished.

# SweetPea Suites APIs Overview

## Available Suites for Sequence/Timeline/Clip Manipulation

### Core Sequence & Clip Suites

**Video Segment Suite** - Parses sequence structure and retrieves details on video segments. It provides a tree-based hierarchy showing compositor nodes, clip nodes, media nodes, and operators (effects). The suite returns queryable properties as strings and includes hash values to detect segment changes.

**Video Segment Render Suite** - Enables built-in software rendering with subtree support, allowing plugins to request the host render specific portions while handling remaining compositing tasks.

**Sequence Info Suite** - Retrieves sequence metadata including "frame size and pixel aspect ratio" and frame rate information. Useful for importers, transitions, and filters needing sequence dimensions.

**Clip Render Suite** - Requests source frames directly from importers, with capabilities to discover supported frame sizes, pixel formats, and retrieve frames synchronously or asynchronously.

### Supporting Suites for Timeline Work

**Time Suite** - Converts between different time representations (ticks per second, video frames, audio samples) and defines frame rate enumerations.

**Marker Suite** - Reads markers of various types attached to sequences.

**Memory Manager Suite** - Manages memory allocation/deallocation and reserves space to prevent cache interference.

**PPix Suite & Related Creator Suites** - Handle pixel frame creation, copying, and buffer access for rendered content.

All suites are accessed through the Utilities Suite via `AcquireSuite()` and must be released when finished.

Based on my search, here's what I found about Premiere Pro SDK, UXP, JavaScript bridge, and C++ native plugin communication:

## Premiere Pro Plugin Development Options

### UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform)
UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level.(no content)You can build performant plugins with modern HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. UXP is the next generation of APIs, for Premiere v25.6 and beyond.

### UXP vs CEP (JavaScript Bridge Differences)
UXP provides a unified JavaScript engine that has direct access to both the Premiere APIs and the UXP Core APIs. This is a big advantage over the previous extensibility technology (CEP), where the communication between the extension logic and the host application happened through a bridge (CSInterface) that passed messages back and forth between the two runtimes. With UXP, everything runs natively in the same environment, and you just need to require() the appropriate modules to access the APIs you need.(no content)UXP Plugins are also JavaScript/HTML/CSS based, however they are built on their own unique stack by Adobe which makes them far less resource heavy than CEP's Node.js + Chromium stack. Additionally instead of a JavaScript frontend and ExtendScript backend like CEP, UXP has 1 unified environment for your frontend code and host API calls, minimizing friction back and forth.

### C++ Hybrid Plugins
UXP has the unique ability of including a C++ Hybrid plugin aspect to run computationally heavy tasks or interact with a host app's C++ APIs directly from the plugin. Note that UXP Hybrid plugins are not yet implemented in Premiere Pro but will be in the future.

### C++ SDK (Native Plugins)
You can build powerful, low-level integrations using C++. The documentation is packaged with the SDK.(no content)The C++ SDK is complete, and used without issue by our C++ plugin developers. The C++ SDK does not contain any CEP or UXP resources.(no content)Many Premiere Pro plugins use the After Effects SDK — They may need the Premiere Pro headers.

### API Behavior Differences
An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous. This means they blocked the Premiere UI while they were executing. In UXP, a method call is asynchronous, and does not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition between the ExtendScript DOM and the UXP DOM, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

### Getting Started
Update your tools: Ensure you have Premiere v25.6 installed. You will also need the latest build, v2.2.1, of the UXP Developer Tools (UDT) to load, debug, and package your plugins. You can download the UDT through Creative Cloud Desktop.

**Key Takeaway:** Currently, there is no direct bridge between UXP JavaScript plugins and C++ native plugins in Premiere Pro. The C++ SDK and UXP are separate systems. UXP Hybrid plugins (which would allow C++ integration from within UXP) are planned but not yet implemented in Premiere Pro.

Based on the search results, here's information about Premiere Pro C++ SDK project structure and building with Visual Studio, Xcode, and CMake:

## Premiere Pro C++ SDK Development Environment

### Official SDK Requirements
The required development environment for Windows is Microsoft Visual Studio 2015 Update 3 on Windows 11. On macOS, the minimum environment is Xcode 16.2 on macOS 15.4 or later. The SDK includes sample projects for these development environments.(no content)The sample code is written in C++. Other compilers and programming languages are not supported.

### Official SDK Project Setup

**Xcode Setup:**
In Xcode, set the build location for the project in File > Project Settings. Press the Advanced button. Under Build Location choose Custom, select Absolute, and set the Products path.

**Visual Studio Setup:**
If you get "Cannot open file '[MediaCore plugins path]plugin.prm'", make sure to launch Visual Studio in administrator mode. In your Visual Studio installation, right-click devenv.exe, Properties > Compatibility > Privilege Level, click "Run this program as an administrator".

### CMake for Cross-Platform Premiere Pro Plugin Development

Unfortunately Adobe provides separate MSVC and Xcode project files, meaning additional build flags and dependencies (like third-party libraries) need to be manually added to each. CMake has become the default 'standard' for cross-platform builds; popularly for C and C++. There is a project that aims to be a good starter for cross-platform Premiere Pro plugin development, including those that have third-party dependencies.(no content)vcpkg is an open-source cross-platform library package management system from Microsoft; targeting macOS, Linux, and Windows. It's very popular, and has strong CMake integration. It is chosen for this project as an example of third-party library integration.(no content)Due to licensing issues, the Adobe SDK cannot be included directly. You must specify it in the build step with `-DADOBE_PP_SDK`.

### General C++ CMake Project Structure

The main idea about project structure is that you have at least 2 folders: `include` and `src`. Headers files in include should be under folder named after your library domain.(no content)For cross-platform builds, CMake can make Xcode project from source code as well as Visual Studio project and so on.

**To generate Xcode projects from CMake:**
You can launch cmake with the parameter `cmake ../Release -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release -G Xcode` to generate an Xcode project.

### Visual Studio CMake Integration

Visual Studio's native support for CMake allows you to edit, build, and debug CMake projects on Windows, the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL), and remote systems from the same instance of Visual Studio. CMake project files (such as CMakeLists.txt) are consumed directly by Visual Studio for the purposes of IntelliSense and browsing. Visual Studio invokes cmake.exe directly for CMake configuration and build.

### Resources

- **Official Premiere Pro SDK Documentation**: [ppro-plugins.docsforadobe.dev](https://ppro-plugins.docsforadobe.dev/intro/sample-projects/)
- **CMake Starter Project for Premiere Pro**: [github.com/SamuelMarks/premiere-pro-cmake-plugin](https://github.com/SamuelMarks/premiere-pro-cmake-plugin)

content.content:
# Premiere Pro SDK Information

## Download Location
The C++ SDK can be accessed through **Adobe's Developer Console** at https://developer.adobe.com/console/servicesandapis/pr. Users experiencing "Restricted Access" errors should log in with a Personal account rather than a corporate one.

## C++ SDK Details
The C++ SDK enables developers to "Build powerful, low-level integrations using C++." Documentation is included with the SDK package itself.

## Plugin Types
Premiere Pro supports three main extension approaches:

1. **UXP Plugins** (Premiere v25.6+) - Modern development using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript for performant plugins
2. **C++ SDK** - Low-level integrations for advanced functionality
3. **CEP Panels** - Classic extensions built with HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and ECMAScript 3

## Getting Started
Visit https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ to begin. Developers can "Seamlessly connect tools in your workflow" to automate tasks, add file format support, design effects, and create custom workspace panels.

content.content:
# Premiere Pro SDK Sample Projects

## Complete Project List

**1. SDK File Importer**
Supports .sdk media files with "uncompressed 8-bit RGB with or without alpha, and packed 10-bit YUV (v410)" formats. Features multistream audio testing capability.

**2. Synth Import**
"Generates 8-bit YUV and RGB, video only" with a settings dialog. Creates synthetic footage demonstrating procedural content generation.

**3. SDK Custom Import**
Similar to Synth Import but "generates it to disk, rather than memory" and can display background timeline frames for titling applications.

**4. Export Controller**
Adds menu functionality to File > Export and demonstrates how to "export a file to C:\Windows\Temp on Windows, or to the Desktop on macOS."

**5. SDK Exporter**
Writes .sdk files with "custom parameters, including a custom settings button" and exports marker data to HTML files.

**6. Transmitter**
Sample audio/video transmit plugin for testing host-plugin interactions without actual hardware output.

**7. SDK_ProcAmp**
"GPU-accelerated effect demonstrates a simple ProcAmp effect" with Metal acceleration support.

**8. Vignette**
Creates vignette effects with "CUDA and software render paths" for both Premiere Pro and After Effects.

**9. SDK_CrossDissolve**
"GPU-accelerated transition demonstrates a simple cross dissolve transition" with CUDA support.

**10. ControlSurface**
Sample control surface integration visible in Preferences menu.

## Timeline/Sequence Manipulation
None of these samples specifically address timeline or sequence manipulation functionality.

Based on the search results, here's information about the Premiere Pro SDK related to sequences, clips, and API headers:

## Premiere Pro SDK - Sequence and Clip API Information

### SDK Documentation
The official Premiere Pro C++ SDK Guide is a living document that is constantly being updated. The latest release of the SDK is available at the Adobe developer portal.

### Key Sequence-Related Suites and Headers

**PrSDKSequenceInfoSuite**
New in CS4, this suite provides calls to get the frame size and pixel aspect ratio of a sequence. This is useful for importers, transitions, or video filters that provide a custom setup dialog with a preview. See PrSDKSequenceInfoSuite.h.(no content)Version 2, new in CS5.5, adds GetFrameRate(). Version 3, new in CC, adds GetFieldType(), GetZeroPoint(), and GetTimecodeDropFrame().(no content)Sequence Info Suite is now at version 5, adding the new call GetImmersiveVideoVRConfiguration(), which returns the VR video settings of the specified sequence.

**Video Segment Suite**
This suite provides calls to parse a sequence and get details on video segments. All the queryable node properties are in PrSDKVideoSegmentProperties.h. These properties will be returned as PrSDKStrings, and should be managed using the String Suite. The segments provide a hash value that the caller can use to quickly determine whether or not a segment has changed.(no content)In version 4, new in CS5.5, the new call AcquireNodeForTime() passes back a segment node for a requested time.

### Clip Manipulation APIs

PrGPUFilterRenderParams has some attributes about an effect or transition, but many things, such as the parameters or duration of the clip to which the plugin is applied, are not found in that structure. These attributes will need to be queried using the GetParam() and GetProperty() helper functions in PrGPUFilterModule.h.(no content)In version 2, new in CS5.5, the new call SupportsInitiateClipPrefetch() can be used to query whether or not a clip supports prefetching.

### Color Space and Sequence Info
Future SDK releases contain PrSDKColorManagementSuite.h for color space management.(no content)The PrSDKSequenceInfoSuite provides GetWorkingColorSpace() which can be used to get an opaque color space ID for the sequence.

### UXP API for Clip/Sequence Manipulation
For the newer UXP API, developers are working with classes like Sequence, ClipProjectItem, and AudioClipTrackItem for adding clips to sequences programmatically.

### SDK Types
The C++ SDK allows building powerful, low-level integrations using C++. The documentation is packaged with the SDK.(no content)The Premiere Pro SDK allows developers to interact with video editing workflows, media files, and UI elements inside Premiere Pro, including Panel Plugins (UXP/CEP Extensions) for custom UI panels and Video Effects Plugins for custom filters, LUTs, and overlays.

input.prompt: Extract all information about legacy callback suites - especially any timeline functions, editing capabilities, or clip manipulation functions

content.content:
# Legacy Callback Suites: Timeline Functions & Clip Manipulation

## Overview
The `piSuites` structure provides access to legacy callback functions organized into five categories: memory, window, PPix, utility, and timeline functions.

## Timeline Functions

The timeline functions enable plugins to interact with sequences and clips:

**Clip Video Retrieval:**
- `getClipVideo`: "Retrieves a frame from a clip in a segment tree returned from the Video Segment Suite." This function is marked as expensive and has been superceded by the Clip Render Suite.
- `getClipVideoEx`: An extended version allowing specification of pixel formats and pixel aspect ratios when retrieving frames.

**Timeline Metadata:**
- `getCurrentTimebase`: Returns the sequence's scale and sample size parameters for timebase calculations.
- `getCurrentPos`: "Returns the position of the current time indicator" or -1 if unavailable.
- `getWorkArea`: Retrieves the start and end points of the current work area.

**Preview Rendering:**
- `getPreviewFrameEx`: "Gets a fully rendered frame from the timeline (all layers)" suitable for filter/transition preview dialogs, not final export.

**Dimension Information:**
- `getClipVideoBounds`: Returns clip dimensions and pixel aspect ratio data.

## Important Notes

These functions are considered legacy. Adobe recommends using modern equivalents like the Clip Render Suite and Video Segment Suite for new development, particularly for asynchronous operations and better performance.

- `getCurrentTimebase`: Returns the sequence's scale and sample size parameters for timebase calculations.
- `getCurrentPos`: "Returns the position of the current time indicator" or -1 if unavailable.
- `getWorkArea`: Retrieves the start and end points of the current work area.

**Preview Rendering:**
- `getPreviewFrameEx`: "Gets a fully rendered frame from the timeline (all layers)" suitable for filter/transition preview dialogs, not final export.

**Dimension Information:**
- `getClipVideoBounds`: Returns clip dimensions and pixel aspect ratio data.

## Important Notes

These functions are considered legacy. Adobe recommends using modern equivalents like the Clip Render Suite and Video Segment Suite for new development, particularly for asynchronous operations and better performance.

Based on my search, here's what I found about Premiere Pro SDK, C++ plugins, and timeline/sequence editing capabilities:

## Premiere Pro C++ SDK Overview

The Adobe Premiere Pro Software Development Kit is a living document that is constantly being updated and edited. The latest release of the SDK is available at https://www.adobe.io/apis/creativecloud/premierepro.html.(no content)The Premiere Pro Software Development Kit enables developers to create plugins for Premiere Pro, After Effects, Audition, Media Encoder, Character Animator, and Premiere Elements.

### Development Requirements

The required development environment for Windows is Microsoft Visual Studio 2015 Update 3 on Windows 11. On macOS, the minimum environment is XCode 16.2 on macOS 15.4 or later. The sample code is written in C++, and other compilers and programming languages are not supported.

### Plugin Types Available

The Premiere Pro SDK allows developers to interact with video editing workflows, media files, and UI elements inside Premiere Pro. Plugin types include Panel Plugins (UXP/CEP Extensions) for custom UI panels and automation, Video Effects Plugins for custom filters/LUTs/overlays, Transition Plugins for custom wipe/dissolve/animation transitions, Audio Effects Plugins, and File Import & Export Automation for batch processing.(no content)For deeper video processing, you can use the C++ SDK to create custom video effects and transitions.

### Timeline Editing API Limitations

Regarding timeline editing capabilities (like cutting clips with a razor tool), the current situation is complicated:

In older versions of Premiere, timeline manipulation could be done through the QE API using functions like: app.enableQE(); clip.moveToTrack(videoIndex, audioIndex); However, in current Premiere Pro builds (2023–2025), this function appears to exist in the QE object model but is not operational.(no content)There have been zero changes to QE DOM APIs, and no such changes are planned or scheduled. However, the QE DOM remains 100% unsupported and not at all recommended.(no content)The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin is the right starting point for any future integrations, and shows how to clone and remove track items.

### C++ SDK Scope

The C++ SDK is complete and used without issue by C++ plugin developers. The C++ SDK does not contain any CEP or UXP resources.(no content)Many Premiere Pro plugins use the After Effects SDK — they may need the Premiere Pro headers.

### Key Takeaway

The **C++ SDK** is primarily designed for:
- Video/audio effects plugins
- Transitions
- Importers/exporters
- Hardware control surfaces
- Transmitters for external monitoring

For **timeline editing operations** (like razor tool, clip cutting, sequence manipulation), the recommended approach now is through **UXP plugins** rather than C++ plugins. Premiere Pro APIs allow you to seamlessly connect tools in your workflow, automate complex tasks, communicate with external hardware, add support for new file formats and codecs, design new effects and transitions, and add panels.

If you need direct timeline manipulation capabilities, you would likely need to explore the UXP JavaScript API rather than the C++ SDK, as the C++ SDK focuses more on media processing rather than timeline editing operations.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Premiere Pro SDK headers, files, and API reference:

## Premiere Pro SDK Overview

The SDK contains headers defining the Premiere Pro APIs, sample projects demonstrating integration features, and the SDK Guide documentation.(no content)Some of the plug-in types described in this SDK can not only run in Premiere Pro, but also After Effects, Encore, Soundbooth, Media Encoder, and Premiere Elements. The After Effects SDK is the recommended SDK for developing effect plug-ins for Premiere Pro and Premiere Elements.

## Where to Get the SDK

The latest release of the SDK is available at: https://www.adobe.io/apis/creativecloud/premierepro.html.(no content)You can build powerful, low-level integrations using C++. The documentation is packaged with the SDK.(no content)If you get "Restricted Access" when trying to download the C++ SDK and documentation, try logging in with a Personal account.

## SDK Completeness and Header Files

The C++ SDK is complete, and used without issue by C++ plugin developers. Also, the C++ SDK does not contain any CEP or UXP resources.(no content)Many Premiere Pro plugins use the After Effects SDK — They may need the Premiere Pro headers.

## Notable SDK Header Files

Some header files mentioned in the documentation include:

- **PrSDKStreamLabel.h** - Defines labels like `kPrSDK_StreamLabelStereoscopicLeft` and `kPrSDKStreamLabel_Stereoscopic_Right`.
- **PrSDKAESupport.h** - Contains the PF Source Settings Suite for effects using the After Effects API.

## API Updates and Changes

For version 13.0, the significant change to Premiere Pro's C++ APIs was the addition of color-space specifiers to the Importer API. The ColorProfileRec structure is deprecated; instead, Importers describe supported colorspaces using a ColorSpaceRec.(no content)GPU-accelerated rendering using Metal is now supported for third-party effects and transitions. PrGPUDeviceFramework_Metal has been added as one of the enum values in PrGPUDeviceFramework.

## Additional Resources

- If you have questions about the APIs, your question may already be answered on the Premiere Pro SDK forum at: https://community.adobe.com/t5/forums/filteredbylabelpage/board-id/premiere-pro/label-name/sdk.

- There is also a newer Premiere API exposed through UXP for developers of plugins and scripts.

- The official SDK Guide is available at: https://ppro-plugins.docsforadobe.dev/

content.content:
# Timeline Editing API Status for Premiere Pro

## Current Limitations

The user reports that **no programmatic method exists** for moving clips between video tracks while preserving timing. Specific findings include:

- The QE API's `moveToTrack()` function appears non-functional in current builds (2023-2025)
- No keyboard-mappable command exists for "Move Clip Up/Down Between Tracks"
- DOM, QE, CEP, and UXP APIs all lack clip relocation capabilities

## Adobe's Response

An Adobe employee (Bruce Bullis) clarified that "there have been zero changes to QE DOM APIs, and no such changes are planned or scheduled." However, the QE DOM remains "100% unsupported, and not at all recommended."

## Recommended Approach

Adobe directs developers to the `premiere_api` UXP example plugin, which demonstrates how to clone and remove track items as workarounds. This suggests **intentional non-support** for direct timeline manipulation rather than technical impossibility.

## Implications

The absence of timeline editing capabilities blocks automation use cases including track consolidation, AI-guided editing, and bulk sequence organization—indicating Adobe maintains this as a deliberate product boundary.

Based on my search, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP API for sequence TrackItem clip manipulation (cut/split):

## Current State of UXP APIs for Premiere Pro (2024-2025)

### UXP Platform Overview
As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform).(no content)UXP is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications, powered by a modern JavaScript engine that offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level.

### Razor Tool / Cut / Split Functionality
**Important limitation:** There is not yet any UXP API that mimics the razor tool. This means programmatically cutting or splitting clips is not currently available through UXP APIs.

### What IS Available for TrackItem Manipulation

Premiere APIs (DOM APIs) give you direct access to Premiere's document model. These APIs let you access and modify projects — sequences, tracks, clips, and markers; work with media — import files, manage project items; control playback — set in/out points, control the playhead; and apply effects — add video and audio effects to clips.

**Available TrackItem operations include:**
- New API to move a trackItem and new APIs to set the disabled state of a trackItem.
- The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin shows how to clone and remove track items.
- Duplicate trackItem using an insert or overwrite edit method to a destination track. Target track and start time of trackItem is determined using an offset value from the original trackItem position.
- Placing trackItems in a sequence = no problem. This is the same for CEP+ExtendScript and UXP.

### Getting Selected Clips
The `getSelection()` method returns currently-selected clips as an Array of TrackItems. Combined with app.bind, you can get real time events of what the selected item is set to using `app.bind("onActiveSequenceSelectionChanged", function () {...})`.

### Track Movement Limitations
There is no current API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks.(no content)The function in QE appears to be stubbed or deprecated without a documented replacement.

### ExtendScript Status
ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.(no content)No further changes to ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled; for now, Adobe is focused on getting UXP extensibility to 1:1 parity with what's possible via CEP+ExtendScript.

### Recent API Updates (March 2025)
There have been updates for UXP APIs including ClipProjectItem API for attach proxy or high resolution footage or replace footage (attachProxy(), changeMediaPath()), EncoderManager API, and SequenceEditor APIs.

### Resources
- The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.
- For UXP-specific discussions, the UXP forum is at: https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/c/uxp-for-premiere-pro/105

Extract the complete table of contents and structure of the C++ SDK documentation - all sections, chapters, and plugin types covered

content.content:
# Premiere Pro C++ SDK Documentation Structure

The documentation is organized into the following major sections:

## Core Sections

**Introduction** - Foundation materials including plugin types, getting started guides, installation, debugging, and best practices

**Resources** - Plugin Property Lists (PiPL) and IMPT resource documentation

**Universals** - Foundational concepts covering "time, video frames, pixel formats and color spaces, pixel aspect ratio, fields, audio, memory management, basic types structures, suites, and callback suites"

**Hardware Integration** - Components, ClassID/Filetype definitions, and ClassData functions

## Plugin Types Covered

1. **Importers** - File import functionality with selectors, structures, return codes, and suites
2. **Exporters** - File export capabilities with comprehensive selector and structure documentation
3. **Video Filters** - Real-time video processing with VideoRecord structures
4. **GPU Effects & Transitions** - GPU-accelerated processing supporting "CUDA, OpenCL, Metal, or OpenGL"
5. **Transmitters** - Module functions and structures for data transmission
6. **Export Controllers** - Export workflow management
7. **AE Transition Extensions** - After Effects transition integration
8. **Control Surfaces** - Hardware control surface integration

## Additional Resources

The guide includes version history, sample projects, localization guidance, and links to "the Adobe Premiere Pro SDK forum" for community support.

# UXP Premiere Pro Sample Plugins

Based on the repository content, here's what's available:

## Sample Plugin Structure

The repository contains a single primary sample plugin called **premiere-api** located in the `sample-panels/premiere-api/html` directory.

## Demonstrated Functionality

The documentation indicates the sample showcases "Premiere Pro's UXP API" capabilities, though specific feature details aren't extensively described in the README. The sample includes:

- Basic panel UI implementation

Based on my search, here's what I found about Premiere Pro's SequenceEditor API methods for insert/overwrite edits in the UXP documentation:

## SequenceEditor API Overview

The SequenceEditor class provides a reference for editing the sequence timeline. The official documentation is available at Adobe's developer site.

## Recent API Updates

Adobe announced updates for UXP APIs in the most recent version of Premiere Pro (Beta), with details available at the documentation website. The SequenceEditor APIs were included in this update along with other features like ClipProjectItem API and EncoderManager API.

## Key Method: createInsertProjectItemAction()

The `createInsertProjectItemAction()` method has the following signature with required parameters: `SequenceEditor.createInsertProjectItemAction(projectItem, TickTime, videoTrackIndex, audioTrackIndex, limitShift)`.

### Important Implementation Notes

When working with SequenceEditor actions, using `lockedAccess` and `executeTransaction` is necessary to make them work properly.

## General UXP API Characteristics

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, meaning they blocked the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread.(no content)For a smooth transition between the ExtendScript DOM and the UXP DOM, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

## Resources

- **Official Documentation**: The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/
- **Sample Plugins**: Adobe provides a third-party sample panel in the premiere-api directory from their Git repository.
- As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP. ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported through September 2026.

For the most detailed and up-to-date information on specific insert and overwrite edit methods, I recommend visiting the official Adobe SequenceEditor documentation page at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/sequenceeditor/.

content.text:
Based on my comprehensive research, here is a detailed report on the Adobe Premiere Pro C++ SDK for building plugins that handle timeline manipulation.

---

# Adobe Premiere Pro C++ SDK Research Report

## 1. What is the Premiere Pro C++ SDK and Where to Download It

The **Adobe Premiere Pro Software Development Kit** enables developers to create native plugins for Premiere Pro, After Effects, Audition, Media Encoder, Character Animator, and Premiere Elements. The SDK allows building powerful, low-level integrations using C++.

**Download Location:**
- Primary source: [Adobe Developer Console](https://developer.adobe.com/console/servicesandapis/pr)
- Alternative portal: https://www.adobe.io/apis/creativecloud/premierepro.html
- Documentation is packaged with the SDK download

**Important Note:** If you encounter "Restricted Access" errors when downloading, log in with a **Personal Adobe account** rather than a corporate account.

**Community Documentation:** The [Premiere Pro C++ SDK Guide](https://ppro-plugins.docsforadobe.dev/) is a community-maintained living document that supplements the official documentation.

---

## 2. Plugin Types That Can Be Built

The C++ SDK supports the following plugin types:

| Plugin Type | Purpose | File Extension |
|-------------|---------|----------------|
| **Importers** | Import video/audio media from files, streams, or generate synthetic content | .prm (Win), .bundle (macOS) |
| **Exporters** | Save media to disk in various formats | .prm / .bundle |
| **Export Controllers** | Drive exporters and perform post-processing (useful for asset management systems) | .prm / .bundle |
| **Video Filters** | Process video frames with animatable parameters (Adobe recommends After Effects SDK instead) | .aex |
| **GPU Effects & Transitions** | GPU-accelerated processing using CUDA, OpenCL, Metal, or OpenGL | .prm / .bundle |
| **Transmitters** | Send video/audio/captions to external devices during playback and editing | .prm / .bundle |
| **Control Surfaces** | Interface with hardware control surfaces for audio mixing, transport, and Lumetri Color panel | .prm / .bundle |

**Additional supported formats:**
- VST/VST3 audio effects
- Audio Units (macOS only)
- After Effects plugins (.aex) - Many Premiere plugins use the After Effects SDK with Premiere Pro headers

---

## 3. Timeline/Sequence Manipulation Capabilities (Critical Finding)

**The C++ SDK does NOT provide direct timeline editing capabilities (cut, razor, split clips).**

This is a significant limitation. The C++ SDK is designed for:
- **Media processing** (effects, transitions, filters)
- **File I/O** (importers, exporters)
- **Hardware integration** (transmitters, control surfaces)
- **Reading sequence data** (querying, not modifying)

**Adobe's Official Stance:**
According to Adobe staff, the QE DOM APIs have had "zero changes" and "no such changes are planned or scheduled." The QE DOM remains "100% unsupported and not at all recommended."

**For timeline editing operations**, Adobe directs developers to:
- **UXP plugins** (JavaScript-based) - which can clone and remove track items
- The `premiere_api` UXP example plugin demonstrates basic track item manipulation

**Current UXP Limitations (as of December 2025):**
- No UXP API mimics the razor tool for cutting/splitting clips
- No API method exists to move clips vertically between tracks
- Insert and overwrite edits are supported via `SequenceEditor.createInsertProjectItemAction()`

---

## 4. Key Classes/APIs for Sequence and Clip Manipulation in C++

While the C++ SDK cannot **modify** timelines, it provides **read-only access** to sequence data through these suites:

### Video Segment Suite
- Header: `PrSDKVideoSegmentSuite.h`, `PrSDKVideoSegmentProperties.h`
- **Purpose:** Parse sequences and retrieve details on video segments
- **Key Features:**
  - Returns a tree-based hierarchy: compositor nodes, clip nodes, media nodes, operators (effects)
  - Provides hash values to detect segment changes
  - `AcquireNodeForTime()` - retrieves segment node for a specific time (CS5.5+)

### Sequence Info Suite
- Header: `PrSDKSequenceInfoSuite.h`
- **Purpose:** Retrieve sequence metadata
- **Key Methods:**
  - `GetFrameRate()` - sequence frame rate
  - `GetFieldType()` - field type information
  - `GetZeroPoint()` - timecode zero point
  - `GetTimecodeDropFrame()` - drop-frame status
  - `GetImmersiveVideoVRConfiguration()` - VR settings
  - `GetWorkingColorSpace()` - color space ID

### Clip Render Suite
- **Purpose:** Request source frames directly from importers
- **Key Features:**
  - Discover supported frame sizes and pixel formats
  - Synchronous and asynchronous frame retrieval
  - `SupportsInitiateClipPrefetch()` - query prefetch support

### Time Suite
- **Purpose:** Convert between time representations
- **Key Features:**
  - Ticks per second calculations
  - Video frame conversions
  - Audio sample conversions
  - Frame rate enumerations

### Legacy Timeline Callbacks (piSuites)
- `getClipVideo()` / `getClipVideoEx()` - retrieve frames from clips (superseded by Clip Render Suite)
- `getCurrentTimebase()` - sequence timebase
- `getCurrentPos()` - current time indicator position
- `getWorkArea()` - work area start/end
- `getPreviewFrameEx()` - fully rendered timeline frame

### Marker Suite
- **Purpose:** Read markers attached to sequences

---

## 5. C++ SDK Bridge/Communication with UXP JavaScript Plugins

**Current State: No Direct Bridge Exists**

The C++ SDK and UXP are **separate, independent systems** with no built-in communication mechanism.

| Technology | Characteristics |
|------------|-----------------|
| **C++ SDK** | Low-level media processing, native code, no UI API access |
| **UXP** | JavaScript/HTML/CSS, direct DOM access, asynchronous, modern UI |
| **CEP (Legacy)** | Node.js + Chromium, ExtendScript backend, CSInterface bridge |

**UXP Hybrid Plugins (Future):**
UXP has the architectural capability to include a "C++ Hybrid plugin aspect to run computationally heavy tasks or interact with a host app's C++ APIs directly." However, **UXP Hybrid plugins are NOT yet implemented in Premiere Pro** but are planned for future releases.

**Current Workarounds:**
- File-based IPC (write/read files for data exchange)
- External process communication via sockets
- Shared memory approaches (complex, unsupported)

---

## 6. Project Structure for a C++ SDK Plugin

### Standard SDK Project Structure

```
MyPlugin/
├── Source/
│   ├── MyPlugin.cpp          # Main entry point
│   ├── MyPlugin.h            # Header file
│   └── MyPluginPiPL.r        # Plugin Property List resource
├── Headers/
│   └── (SDK headers referenced)
├── Resources/
│   └── (Icon files, etc.)
├── Build/
│   ├── Win/
│   │   └── MyPlugin.vcxproj  # Visual Studio project
│   └── Mac/
│       └── MyPlugin.xcodeproj # Xcode project
└── Output/
    └── MyPlugin.prm/.bundle
```

### Plugin Property List (PiPL) Resource
Every Premiere plugin requires a PiPL resource that defines:
- Plugin type and version
- Entry point name
- Supported hosts
- Resource flags

### Key Files
- **Entry Point:** Single entry point per plugin (unlike After Effects which supports multiple)
- **Output Extension:** `.prm` (Windows), `.bundle` (macOS)

---

## 7. Build Tools Required

### Windows
- **Microsoft Visual Studio 2015 Update 3** (minimum required)
- Windows 11 (required development environment)
- Administrator mode may be required for debugging

### macOS
- **Xcode 16.2** (minimum required)
- macOS 15.4 or later

### CMake (Community Alternative)
Adobe provides separate MSVC and Xcode project files. For cross-platform development, a community project exists:
- [premiere-pro-cmake-plugin](https://github.com/SamuelMarks/premiere-pro-cmake-plugin)
- Uses vcpkg for dependency management
- Requires specifying SDK path: `-DADOBE_PP_SDK`

**Generate Xcode from CMake:**
```bash
cmake ../Release -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release -G Xcode
```

**Important:** The Adobe SDK cannot be redistributed due to licensing; it must be specified separately in build configuration.

---

## 8. Sample Projects Included in SDK

| Sample | Description | Timeline Relevance |
|--------|-------------|-------------------|
| **SDK File Importer** | Supports .sdk files with 8-bit RGB/alpha and 10-bit YUV | None |
| **Synth Import** | Generates synthetic 8-bit YUV/RGB video | None |
| **SDK Custom Import** | Generates to disk, can display background timeline frames (for titlers) | Limited (read-only) |
| **Export Controller** | Demonstrates File > Export menu integration | None |
| **SDK Exporter** | Writes .sdk files with custom parameters, exports markers to HTML | None |
| **Transmitter** | Sample A/V transmit plugin | None |
| **SDK_ProcAmp** | GPU-accelerated ProcAmp effect (Metal support) | None |
| **Vignette** | Vignette effect with CUDA and software paths | None |
| **SDK_CrossDissolve** | GPU-accelerated cross dissolve transition (CUDA) | None |
| **ControlSurface** | Hardware control surface integration | None |

**None of the official sample projects demonstrate timeline/sequence manipulation** because the C++ SDK does not support those operations.

For timeline manipulation examples, refer to the UXP samples at [AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples](https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples), specifically the `premiere-api` sample which demonstrates track item cloning and removal.

---

## Summary and Recommendations

### C++ SDK Is Appropriate For:
- Custom video/audio effects and transitions
- New file format importers/exporters
- Hardware transmitters for external monitoring
- Control surface integration
- High-performance GPU-accelerated processing

### C++ SDK Is NOT Appropriate For:
- Timeline editing (cut, razor, split clips)
- Moving clips between tracks
- Sequence manipulation
- Project organization automation

### For Timeline Manipulation, Consider:
1. **UXP plugins** (Premiere v25.6+) - Modern JavaScript-based approach with limited but growing timeline APIs
2. **ExtendScript/CEP** (supported through September 2026) - Legacy but more feature-complete
3. **Waiting for UXP Hybrid** - Future capability that will bridge UXP JavaScript with C++ code

---

## Sources

- [Premiere Pro C++ SDK Guide](https://ppro-plugins.docsforadobe.dev/)
- [Adobe Developer Portal - Premiere Pro](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/)
- [Premiere Pro Plugin Types](https://ppro-plugins.docsforadobe.dev/intro/premiere-pro-plugin-types/)
- [SweetPea Suites Documentation](https://ppro-plugins.docsforadobe.dev/universals/sweetpea-suites/)
- [Sample Projects Documentation](https://ppro-plugins.docsforadobe.dev/intro/sample-projects/)
- [Adobe Community - Timeline Editing API Request](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-ideas/request-for-timeline-editing-api-support-clip-track-movement-flattening/idc-p/15625115)
- [Premiere Pro UXP API Documentation](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/)
- [UXP Premiere Pro Samples GitHub](https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples)
- [premiere-pro-cmake-plugin GitHub](https://github.com/SamuelMarks/premiere-pro-cmake-plugin)
- [GitHub - docsforadobe/premiere-plugin-guide](https://github.com/docsforadobe/premiere-plugin-guide)
